title: R43557
content: The report provides an overview of FY2015 legislative branch appropriations, detailing actions such as the submission of requests, hearings, markups, and passage of relevant bills. It also covers prior year actions and funding, budget requests, hearings, and funding issues for legislative branch agencies. Tables list funding levels for FY2014 and FY2015 budget requests. The FY2015 U.S. Budget was submitted on March 4, 2014, requesting $4.471 billion in new budget authority for legislative branch activities. Hearings and markups were conducted in 2014, with the House subcommittee providing $3.3 billion in funding. No amendments were offered during the markup process. Table 2 lists the dates of hearings of the legislative branch subcommittees in 2014. Prepared statements of witnesses were posted on the subcommittee websites. On April 4, 2014, the House subcommittee met to mark up the FY2015 bill, providing $3.3 billion in funding. The full House Appropriations Committee held a markup on April 9, 2014, where one amendment was considered. Representative Moran proposed a housing stipend for Members living 50 or more miles away from DC, which failed. The House of Representatives considered H.R. 4487 on May 1, 2014, with eight amendments, including one to prohibit funding through the Member Representational Allowance for vehicle leasing, which failed by a vote of 196-221. Eight amendments were considered, including: an amendment to prohibit funding for vehicle leasing through the Member Representational Allowance, which failed by a vote of 196-221; an amendment to appropriate $500,000 for sexual harassment training for House offices, which was agreed to by voice vote; an amendment to reduce funding for the Botanic Garden to FY2014 levels and transfer funds to the spending reduction account, which was agreed to by a vote of 219-198; an amendment to reduce funding for the Capitol Visitor Center by $243,000, returning it to FY2014 levels, which failed by a vote of 207-212; and an amendment to defund the Open World Leadership Center Trust Fund, which failed by voice vote. An amendment to reduce funding for the Capitol Visitor Center by $243,000 failed by a vote of 207-212. Another amendment to defund the Open World Leadership Center Trust Fund also failed. However, amendments to prohibit funds for printed copies of certain documents were agreed to by voice vote. Additionally, an amendment to reinstitute the Office of Technology Assessment with $2.5 million from the House Historic Buildings Revitalization Trust Fund failed. H.R. 4487, as amended, was passed by the House with a vote of 402-14. The House failed an amendment to reinstitute the Office of Technology Assessment with $2.5 million from the House Historic Buildings Revitalization Trust Fund. H.R. 4487, as amended, passed by the House with a vote of 402-14. The Senate Appropriations Committee considered H.R. 4487 on June 19, 2014, ordering the bill reported favorably with an amendment. No further action was taken on H.R. 4487 before the start of FY2015. Funding for the legislative branch was provided through continuing appropriations resolutions until the Consolidated and Further Continuing Appropriations Act, 2015, was enacted on December 16, 2014. The legislative branch faced a funding gap in FY2014, leading to a partial government shutdown for 16 days. This was resolved by the enactment of a continuing resolution (CR) on October 17, 2013. Subsequent funding was provided through a consolidated appropriations bill, totaling $4.259 billion for FY2014. This amount was higher than the FY2013 funding of $4.061 billion, which was enacted in March 2013. The legislative branch funding for FY2013 was enacted on March 26, 2013, at the FY2012 level with exceptions and rescissions.
